newsitem.title: USA: Starbucks sets sights on Florida.
newsitem.headline: Starbucks sets sights on Florida.

text.p: Starbucks Corp said Friday it is confident it can sell its upscale coffee in Miami, although the city of hot sun, beaches and cool drinks is a far cry from the company's cloudy, chilly Seattle base.
"People drink coffee everywhere," Starbucks zone vice president Marcia Adams told Reuters in an interview at the company's new store in the Miami suburb Coral Gables.
Adams said the company's current plan is to open 13 standalone stores in Florida, all in Dade, Broward and Palm Beach counties by the end of September.
"Florida has a very high coffee consumption rate compared to the rest of the country," she said.
Company officials were in southern Florida Friday for the opening of its first two standalone stores in the state, both in suburbs of Miami. A third was expected to open within days.

Adams would not project sales figures but said Starbucks did not anticipate problems winning an audience in Miami, although she acknowledged that the area is known best for "cafe cubano," thimble-sized plastic cups of sugar-sweetened espresso brought to Florida by the Cuban-American community.

"We can make coffee any way anyone wants it. If they can tell us what they want, we can make it for them," she said. She also noted the market for Cuban coffee, which sells for about $0.30 at utilitarian walkup windows, is different from the crowds drawn to Starbucks' cafe atmosphere, where an iced coffee drink can cost as much as $3.85 and an espresso $1.00.

The company opted not to translate its signs into Spanish -- the native tongue of an estimated 60 percent of people in the Miami area -- although about half the staff hired in the region speak the language.

"We talked about it and we really felt we needed to come into the market as a true Starbucks," she said. She said Starbucks had done a strong mail order business in the region even before it decided to open stores here.
